timeline.bodyText: this is probably a bad example of how to use a counter. Counters are intended to be used as a part of a "synchronous" measurement, associated with a span context. Measuring jvm memory usage is a better use-case for an Observer instrument.
timeline.author: jkwatson

replies.bodyText: @jkwatson maybe u have smth on mind to count wia double counter?
replies.author: DotSpy

replies.bodyText: I don't. I'm not sure what a use-case is for counting things that are non-integer valued. Maybe total number of kilobytes processed in some kind of web request?
replies.author: jkwatson

replies.bodyText: but they are also int
replies.author: DotSpy

replies.bodyText: you can have fractional kb, though, right?
replies.author: jkwatson

replies.bodyText: ok i got smth on my mind
replies.author: DotSpy

timeline.bodyText: Please add Javadoc explaining the purpose of the example.
timeline.author: jkwatson

timeline.bodyText: I think it would be helpful to have the meter name reflect reommended meter naming standards, which would mean this should probably be something like "io.opentelemetry.example.metrics" with a version of 0.5, maybe
timeline.author: jkwatson
thisthat

timeline.bodyText: Same comment about using a synchronous instrument for doing what should be an asynchronous measurement. We should make sure our examples are using the APIs idiomatically. In general, synchronous instruments should be used to instrument code executing within a span context.
timeline.author: jkwatson

timeline.message: feat: metrics examples adding bound() and applying review comments

timeline.bodyText:
This should be renamed to LongCounterExample, and it still needs to have a span context surrounding the usage of the counter, to be idiomatically correct.
The javadoc should definitely be more descriptive, and probably include a reference to the relevant section of the metric specifications. It should explain under what circumstances it is appropriate to use a LongCounter, and explain what "bound" means. My expectation is that a newbie who is looking at this code will see an idiomatic example of how to use the instrument being demonstrated and understand why and when they would use such an instrument.
timeline.author: jkwatson

replies.bodyText: @jkwatson gotch you
replies.author: DotSpy

timeline.bodyText: I think you missed my point here. The javadoc should explain what the example is trying to teach. We aren't trying to teach people how to traverse directory structures. We're trying to teach people how to use a Counter, a LongCounter in particular.
timeline.author: jkwatson

That example trying to show usage of LongCounter, so as i understand u JD will look like
Example of using LongCounter and BoundCounters to count searched directories.

replies.bodyText: but, the name of the instrument already has this same information in it, so why would you add a redundant label? You might add a bound label for the disk volume, or the host name, or something that would not just repeat the information that is in the instrument name.
replies.author: jkwatson

timeline.bodyText: As above, the javadoc should explain what we're trying to teach people with the example.

timeline.bodyText: this usage should also be in a Span scope, like in the LongCounterExample.
timeline.author: jkwatson

timeline.bodyText: Move the creation of the counter up out of the try block. We only need to use the counter inside a span context, not create it.
timeline.author: jkwatson

timeline.message: feat: move creation of counter out of try block

timeline.bodyText:
Is a counter really the right instrument type to use here?
I thought this was only used for things that you actually count, like, the number of requests, errors or total bytes written or something like this. In particular, things where one would be interested in the total sum only and not distinct values or their min/max. Of course one could argue that measuring time entails counting seconds but I thought the ValueRecorder would be the correct instrument to record such distinct measurements.
The spec even mentions:

Example uses for ValueRecorder that are non-additive:

capture any kind of timing information


Also the example in the Javadoc even demonstrates how it's used to report timings:
https://github.com/open-telemetry/opentelemetry-java/blob/master/api/src/main/java/io/opentelemetry/metrics/DoubleValueRecorder.java
timeline.author: arminru

replies.bodyText: @arminru you are correct, also I think our examples should try to follow these recommendations.
replies.author: bogdandrutu

replies.bodyText: Do we know what a DoubleCounter would be used to count? Seems like an odd thing to count fractional stuff.
replies.author: jkwatson

replies.bodyText: @jkwatson Good question. If one would use MB as a unit of bytes written to disk, for example, fractions would make sense -- but it would probably make even more sense to use KB or B if one is interested in such a precision.
replies.author: arminru

replies.bodyText: I wonder, if we don't have a good use-case for it, if we should consider removing it from the API.
replies.author: jkwatson

replies.bodyText: @jkwatson Fair point. I think it makes sense to consider it but it might only be us not being able to come up with a good example. The example in DoubleCounter's Javadoc is slightly contrived but I could imagine that there are reasonable use cases for it out in the wild. Apart from that, removing it might be surprising to users for the lack of symmetry in the API then.
replies.author: arminru

timeline.bodyText: Leftover, this example is not about finding any files.
timeline.author: arminru

timeline.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
             * Example of using {@link DoubleCounter} and {@link DoubleCounter.BoundDoubleCounter} to count used space by file  with specific extension.
          
          
            
             * Example of using {@link DoubleCounter} and {@link DoubleCounter.BoundDoubleCounter} to count disk space used by files with a specific extension.
timeline.author: arminru

timeline.bodyText:
Actually you don't use the BoundDoubleCounter or labels here at all, or am I missing something? 😅
The file extension would actually make a great metric dimension/label in your example.
disk_space_used[file_extension=dll]:   5 MB
disk_space_used[file_extension=pdf]:   1 MB
disk_space_used[file_extension=png]: 710 MB

and so on.
What do you think? 🙂
timeline.author: arminru

replies.bodyText: we can throw away labels from this example if it misleading
replies.author: DotSpy

replies.bodyText: You already demonstrate how to use them with the file extensions, so dropping them here and reporting only total or free would be fine, I guess. In this case I'd name the metric jvm.memory.total or jvm.memory.free to specify which kind memory is being reported.
replies.author: arminru
